title: Permotanyderus
text:
Permotanyderus is an extinct <a href="genus">genus</a> of <a href="protodiptera">protodiptera</a>n <a href="insect">insect</a> of the <a href="Permotanyderidae">Permotanyderidae</a> family, first described by Edgar F. Riek in Australia in 1953 and which contains a single species "P. ableptus".
Evidence of the presence of <a href="Diptera">Diptera</a> or their direct predecessors in the <a href="Upper%20Permian">Upper Permian</a> of Australia is shown by the presence of <a href="Mecoptera">Mecoptera</a> in those formations. The <a href="Paratrichoptera">Paratrichoptera</a> of the Upper Permian probably, and those of the Triassic certainly, have been considered survivors of the maternal group. Riek described in 1953 two species of protodipteran of the Upper Permian of Australia: "Permotanyderus ableptus" and "<a href="Choristotanyderus%20nanus">Choristotanyderus nanus</a>" joining "<a href="Permotipula%20patricia">Permotipula patricia</a>" named by Tillyard in 1929, but these cannot be attributed to any of the sub-groups of the dipterans or their direct predecessors.
